thread.title: Asian Futures Mixed After Tech Slump; Kiwi Jumps After Rate Cut
thread.title_full: Asian Futures Mixed After Tech Slump; Kiwi Jumps After Rate Cut - Bloomberg Business

author: Emma O'Brien
title: Asian Futures Mixed After Tech Slump; Kiwi Jumps After Rate Cut
text:
Asian stock futures were mixed following a selloff in commodities and technology shares, while New Zealand’s dollar gained as the central bank omitted a reference to its level being unjustified after cutting interest rates.
Japanese index futures climbed in most recent trading, while contracts on Hong Kong equity gauges retreated. Futures on the Nasdaq 100 Index added 0.1 percent by 7:27 a.m. in Tokyo after Apple Inc. drove a 1.1 percent decline in the index. The kiwi climbed 1.1 percent against the dollar, erasing Wednesday’s 0.8 percent drop, after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand predicted inflation will return to near targets next year even as the economy softens. U.S. crude and gold maintained losses. Copper futures rose.
Better-than-expected earnings from Boeing Co. to Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. tempered the impact of losses among technology companies and Apple suppliers worldwide Wednesday. A gauge of commodities returned to a 13-year low, with a rout that started in gold infecting other metals, oil and farm products. South Korea updates on growth Thursday, while Japan reports trade. U.S. jobs data is due, with traders trying to gauge the timing for the first rate increase there since 2006.
“An absence of macro data had investors focused on earnings results, which were more mixed than investors cared for,” Matthew Sherwood, head of investment markets research in Sydney at Perpetual Ltd., which manages about $21 billion, wrote in an e-mail. “High beta currencies depreciated against a stronger greenback and commodities were lower.”
Not Dovish The kiwi rose to 66.45 U.S. cents and gained 0.9 percent against neighboring Australia’s dollar. Despite the rate cut, the central bank’s statement “was not as dovish as markets were prepared for, particularly concerning the exchange rate,” economists at Westpac Banking Corp. in Auckland wrote in a client note after the decision.
Yields on New Zealand’s 10-year government bonds fell two basis points, or 0.02 percentage point, to 3.42 percent, while the NZX 50 Index slipped 0.3 percent in early trading.
The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, a gauge of the U.S. currency versus 10 major peers, rose 0.3 percent Wednesday, its fifth advance in six days. The yen was little changed for a second day, at 123.96 per dollar, while the euro was at $1.0926. Commodity currencies led losses last session, with the Brazilian real, Canadian dollar and South African rand down at least 0.7 percent.
In the equity futures market, contracts on Japan’s Nikkei 225 Stock Average climbed 0.4 percent to 20,640 by 3 a.m. in Osaka.
China Futures Futures on Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 Index were down less than 0.1 percent amid the commodities slump, and contracts on the Kospi index in Seoul were also little changed with those on the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, which tracks mainland stocks listed in Hong Kong. Hang Seng Index futures lost 0.2 percent, while contracts on the FTSE China A50 Index added 0.2 percent. CSI 300 Index futures fell 0.6 percent.
Gold for immediate delivery was little changed at $1,094.83 an ounce after sinking 0.6 percent last session, while copper futures on the Comex added 0.2 percent to $2.4325 a pound following Wednesday’s 1.9 percent slide. The Bloomberg Commodity Index sank 1.1 percent last session to its lowest close since April 2002, led by metals and crude oil.
West Texas Intermediate crude was little changed at $49.25 a barrel after slipping 3.3 percent Wednesday to its lowest level since the start of April. WTI is approaching a bear market again, down almost 20 percent in six weeks amid resurgent concerns over a global supply glut.
U.S. oil inventories rose by 2.47 million barrels last week, Energy Information Administration data showed, defying the 2.2 million-barrel drop forecast by analysts. Supplies climbed as refineries processed crude at a record pace and the nation’s oil output was steady near the highest level in more than 40 years.
